results.title: Backbone of the club
results.brief_description:
They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

Contributors

Terms of use

Copyright
Malcolm McKinnon, 2006.

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

JAN ENDERS: I’ve had three sons play over the years. And I get on well with the ladies, so I’ll turn up and help. We never miss the footy. We like away games because we can watch. Home games, I have most to do with the lolly stall and keeping the drinks in the fridge and backing up in the kitchen. We sometimes see the last quarter. Don’t see much else.

[SEWING MACHINE WHIRRING]

I do all the sewing, and if there’s any repairs, I take them home, bring them back Saturday morning. Our thirds and reserves won last year, and we’ve always let them have their jumpers. So you order your jumpers very early and you don’t know what players you’re going to have in sizes. So I’ve probably sewed on 100 numbers prior to the start of the season.

ROE HARRAP: I started off going with a guy who played here, ended up marrying him, and now my children are playing here. So yeah, it really is a family affair.

[LAUGHTER]

Women are at backbone s of the football club here. I believe that women play a huge role in country football. And particularly here, if he didn’t have the women behind the club, they wouldn’t be where they are now.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: Oh, I love the club, and I love all the people. We’re all good friends. Actually, last week we were very short in the seconds. I got named as an emergency on the bench.

[LAUGHTER]

But this way, I think I got more players back. I said, well, just get me some boots and I’ll be right.

group_siblings.title: Looking for a game at Lake Tyers

results.title: [Stelarc: Stretched Skin No.4 Munich 1977]
results.brief_description:
This video footage is of a suspension performance entitled “Event for Stretched Skin No. 4” that took place at the Art Academy in Munich, Germany on 8 August 1977.

As the name suggests, this was Stelarc’s fourth suspension performance, in which the artist’s body is suspended in space by a series of hooks inserted into the skin. The artist began performing these durational performances in Japan in 1976; this was his first international performance.

In the video, we see the hooks being pierced into the skin across the back and front of the body. The body is then suspended upside down from a sculptural structure made out of logs of wood. The body hangs with arms outstretched in front of the windows of the Art Academy, showing Munich in the background. The performance is observed by a team of assistants, photographers and a small audience.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976]
results.brief_description:
This video is documentation of a performance entitled “Modulate / Meditate: Event for Modified Man” held at Tamura Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, from 26 January to 1 February 1976.

In this durational performance, Stelarc has hooks inserted into his back and sews first his lips and then his eyelids closed with a needle and thread. In the gallery are TV monitors including one showing an X-ray of his own body. Standing in the centre of the gallery with the hooks attached to the wall behind him, the artist captures the sounds of his own body – heartbeat, breath and blood rushing – which are then amplified throughout the space. In the latter part of the video, the participation of the body comes to an end: the artist removes the stitches from his eyelids and mouth and the hooks are removed.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: Preserving native grasslands
results.creator_credit: Conservation Forrest and Lands and Victoria. Dept of Conservation, Forests and Lands
results.brief_description: This program examines the problem of our disappearing native grasslands due to the urban sprawl, introduced species and weeds. The department of Conservation, Forests and Land have put out a booklet promoting public awareness of native plants (grasses, flowers and herbs), when and how to identify them, and the various steps involved in preserving them. No other credits available.

results.title: More or less: a film about food
results.creator_credit: Lawrie Whittle, Paddy Stitt and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: Andrew Daddo outlines the “More or less” diet which is advocated by the Life Be In It campaign as a plan for eating for the “rest of your life”. By choosing carefully from the five basic food groups and eating more bread, cereals, fruit and vegetables, and less sugar, fat and salt, and exercising regularly, more children can became aware of the choices involved in planning a balanced diet.

results.title: Visions of perfection
results.creator_credit: Diane Charleson, Prahran School Support Centre and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: The Victoria College of the Arts provides a venue for talented children in the performing arts of music and dance to combine these with their academic studies in a high school setting. A student violinist, percussionist, ballet dancer and pianist talk about the courses available and demonstrate some of the activities in the school.

results.title: Handicap is something you put on a horse
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton, Joan Reidy, Marjorie Fisher and I E A
results.brief_description: A documentation of the successful integration of a physically disabled person into the field of journalism. Stresses the importance of commencing the integration pocess at an early age and mantaining the integrated contact as the dissabled person matures.

results.title: One drink away
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Geoff Owen-Taylor, HSV7 and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Looks closely at alcoholism within the community and the devastating effects it can have on the home and industry. The organizations set up to help alcoholics and their families are also discussed. Hosted by Dan Webb.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeff Spencer, Geoff Owen-Taylor, HSV7 and Victoria. Ministry of Education
